title: I think the balance team just doesn't really play the game.
body:
At this point, after the amount I've read, played, watched, and waited, I don't think there's any conceivable conclusion to the atrocious current balance state.

This is easy to fix. If someone on the balance team sees this, please consider it. I'm not trying to be cruel (I apologize if I come off that way). If some Rioter could drop in ang give some info on the state of the balance team's playing schedule that would be fantastic, if I'm wrong so be it. But if this isn't the reason I think League is going to be in trouble for a long, long time.

 {{champion:114}}  {{champion:104}} {{champion:41}} and others like them are still unbelievably toxic, and it doesn't take too many games to realize that. {{champion:5}} is absurd and {{champion:238}} doesn't have much risk involved for an assassin of his caliber. Champions like {{champion:113}} and {{champion:14}} have almost been straight up abandoned. Marksmen are everywhere just because armor itemization is garbage now and ad itemization is amazing.

 It feels like you could drag a group of 8 or so people who play a mere single game a day with no data or statistics and they'd do much better at getting the game in a healthy state. I miss the days of being able to see {{champion:32}} {{champion:79}} {{champion:59}} {{champion:111}} {{champion:76}} {{champion:33}} {{champion:48}} or {{champion:62}} in the jungle and not having inherent disadvantages other than those that were created when comparing team compositions and counterplay options for the enemy team.

Towers feel like garbage. 

Getting 2-3 inhibitors destroyed might as well be a death sentence unless you have an enemy inhib down yourself.

It feels like individual classes reach their mid/late game status sooner than others.

The game just in general feels less fun, and I'm sure something would've been done about it by now if the balance team actually noticed it.

replies.body: This seems more about what you read here then what you actually experienced in a game.
I dont remember a single time since the start of season 2 (because the community was much smaller back then) where old GD/Boards didnt deem the game as literally unplayable and broken

During the Cinderhulk meta there were calls to nerf the item itself but I think many people can agree League was very balanced and enjoyable back then. Of course some champions like Sejuani were considerably strong but got nerfed appropriately (and then overly nerfed when the item was hit hard.) but overall the state of the game was enjoyable where most champions were viable.

Dont know what kind of rose colored glasses youre looking through. 

There was never a point in the game where "most of the champions were viable".

Tanks were viable and some were a bit too strong but they were definitely really good.

Marksmen were viable because they were the only ones who could counter tanks.

Assassins were viable because they were the only ones who could counter Marksmen while being countered by Tanks.

Not all champions were viable don't get me wrong, but definitely a majority of the game was at a viably playable level.

And mages were at an all-time low.  Oh, and assassins didn't actually get played because the best mids were Urgot and Cho.

I don't know about you, but the patches before Cinderhulk got nerfed and there were 3 tanks and a bruiser on every team were horrible.  Now, if you're talking about the post-nerf Cinderhulk meta, with midlane bruisers and smite tops gone, that's another story.

Mages? You mean the champions who currently have subpar itemization, are countered by nearly every common Mid laner, and most of them having massive issues with their own kits. Mages weren't necessarily god-tier during Cinderhulk era but they definitely were noticeably stronger.
they don't actually play the game they just troll the forums. Why riot barely makes changes to the game that these people suggest.

3. Complain about towers

> If some Rioter could drop in ang give some info on the state of the balance team's playing schedule that would be fantastic, if I'm wrong so be it.

Varies member to member.  I'm probably on the low end so far as I tend to play in spurts.  Some months I'll only get ~30 ranked games, others (generally when I'm shooting for the next rank) I'll play over 100.  My boy Smash already has about 150 games into this season.  I think he's winning.

Outside of ranked/normals/arams which I do on my own time, we also do multiple playtests per day.  I'm normally in two: one for experimental changes / new champions and then another that's generally focused on next patch balancing.  

Additionally we have a whole crew of beastmode playtesters who do at least four playtests a day to gather feedback and then play unholy amounts of Live because they love the game. They help inform us on all the decisions we make.  

Not saying there aren't balance problems. But they're not for lack of us loving/playing the game or trying to make it better for players.

Then why have these problems the guy posted still going on for so long? I mean, go ahead. Nerf Zed and others more. Listen to us when we say not to go through with changes like the Xin Chao buffs, which you went ahead and did anyway.

Can you see how we are so frustrated?

I do see. 

It's unfortunately easy to put together a list of things that frustrate you about the game. In bug chunks it is difficult to respond to all those opinions.  Singurytas addressed a lot of the points in the original post with his separate opinions (below), most of which I agree with.


To address the first points re {{champion:41}} {{champion:114}} : We have changes on the way for them.  We probably went too far with {{champion:5}} love and also have plans to tune him in 6.4.
Why did you buff Xin in the first place?
They explained it in the patch notes. They wanted to give him more build diversity. Unfortunately they didn't bother to give compensation nerfs to his current popular build.

Okay, then why was Swain nerfed preemptively, yet Xin was given buffs? How is that even remotely the same balance philosophy?

(we'll ignore how badly OP GP and FIora have been at pro level for months)

It still does not explain why you allowed the xin buffs to go through in the first place.

Whats the point of a pbe of you dont listen to the feed back.
pls give xin level love to champs who need it.... like aatrox who really needs a rework as his lore based identity doesn't even match his gameplay

I'd really like to know your personal opinion on the GP changes.
If you can't give me those, or just don't want to, that's fine.

But it would be awesome if you could tell me if you will still be playing GP next patch?
I'm assuming you've had to chance to play around with him a little :p
{{summoner:31}}

My personal opinion is a bit biased because I'm in charge of those changes.  If we didn't think he'd still be worth playing, we wouldn't ship the changes. 

I am sure I will still play him. Not as much, though.  For one, I'm trying to support main this season. For two, I'll basically pick him blind nowadays,  without regard for team setups. This might make me think twice about purposefully picking him into a losing match up, which I think is fair. 

I think you asked me in a separate thread if I found him fun or just powerful.  It's very hard to distinguish the two. I like winning a lot, but I think it's fair to say his pattern is more engaging than most. I also tend to gravitate towards top laners who have pretty good utility.  In his case, I got good utility (cross-map ults) and the ability to carry games.

{{summoner:31}}
Can you give context as to why the Xin buffs went through? That's just sticks out as a perfect example of "they don't play the game" buff.

Read. The. Goddamn. Patch. Notes.

> Xin Zhao's been left in the dust as far as stabbin' folks goes, underperforming in every role across the board. One of our old-school 'melee carries', Xin's always had a lot of flexibility in builds - able to swap between 'max cooldown lockdown machine' or 'crit-fueled basic-attacking monster' based on his team's needs. That said, itemization changes in 2016 have impacted that flexibility pretty heavily. These changes are aimed at bringing back Xin's ability to opt-in to an early snowball rather than feeling pressured to always aim for the lategame (via Sated Devourer and Guinsoo's on-hit synergies).

> A point of clarification: To those of you worried about Xin's new crit mechanic's getting out of control with the already-popular Sated Devourer builds, it's important to note that the crit occurs every third attack, not every third hit. This means Sated's Phantom Hit passive won't let him double down into more crits, so you're better off with regular ol' attack damage and attack speed to make the most of his new Battle Cry. 

They ALWAYS give you context behind the changes being made.

>These changes are aimed at bringing back Xin's ability to opt-in to an early snowball rather than feeling pressured to always aim for the lategame (via Sated Devourer and Guinsoo's on-hit synergies).

And that's COUNTER to what happened. He wasn't given +2 armour or dmg at level 1. He wasn't strengthen early. He was made a stronger mid-game bruiser, and a much stronger late game carry. So no, the patch notes did not do what the "goal" was.

Thanks for dropping in and giving some context! You mentioned multiple playtests per day. Just wondering, what are these? Like specific scenarios set up with specific champs and items? Sorry if I came off as crude or whatever, I gotta admit I was in a bad mood when I wrote this post {{sticker:zombie-brand-facepalm}} 

How long have you been playing the game, and do you agree with the general idea that the cinderhulk meta was the healthiest the game has seen thus far? I don't mean to circlejerk the idea around more, but I don't remember much around that time that especially dominated play at all levels.

> You mentioned multiple playtests per day. Just wondering, what are these? Like specific scenarios set up with specific champs and items?

Yah you got the right idea.  We have a bunch of test points, which could be new champions, balance changes, new items, mastery changes, or anything you'll ever see changed in the game, basically.  We try to keep the number of test points down so we have a decent idea of how it would play out in a usual game of LoL.  

> How long have you been playing the game, and do you agree with the general idea that the cinderhulk meta was the healthiest the game has seen thus far?

I think since midway through Season 1.  

Not really for Cinderhulk.  My recollection of that was Sejuani was super strong, and a lot of people were complaining about Nunu standing on them.  I PERSONALLY like that type of meta because I play tank junglers and supports who work well with tanks but I don't think we were really patting ourselves on the back at the time.  I don't think I could objectively assess the state of the game almost a year ago esp. without overlooking some of the downsides.

Sorry but multiple playtests by a small pool of players who have their own biases generated from their obligations to the company as well as varying skill levels and often, limited mindsets is NOT enough to generate valid reasons for the changes that are often overdone.

I like how a Rioter finally comes off more aggressive and direct. It makes me feel like you're an actual person with their own opinion. A lot of other Rioters just comment passively and totally avoid any posts with potential conflict towards them.
So they're just there because you guys are bad at your job?  Well at least you love and play the game.

Zed's safe for an assassin.

Yeah that's because unless you're an immobile champion with no flash, no hourglass or QSS, or a defensive summoner or exhaust, he can't kill you.

I'm not saying he's top tier at any of those things, but it seems like most of the options for counterplay apply to every assassin in the game save for QSS (which is kind of a waste of money since it gives MR instead of ad and doesn't build into any ap options).

He has weaknesses, yeah I agree. But he's nigh impossible to gank unless he uses his shadow and doesn't back off if he has no vision, and unless he's just a bad player he shouldn't be missing any cs thanks to his waveclear and passive.

When I started playing this game, a lot of more experienced people told me they balance around the LCS (which is crazy since it doesn't account for even more than 1% of the community).

IIRC, they stated that they balance around Platinum and higher with a focus on LCS.

Frankly, balancing around higher-tier play is typically the best option.  It is easier to identify whether or not a champion's kit is imbalanced since all players involved are playing their champions at or near the highest level of skill.  In lower ELOs, player skill is far more influential due to the numerous mistakes dominating every game.

While you occasionally have to factor in pub-stompers dominating lower-tier play, they are typically strong due to their enemies incompetence and inability to take advantage of their weaknesses.

I agree mostly with your post, except:

>Marksmen are everywhere just because armor itemization is garbage now and ad itemization is amazing.

With *options* such as {{item:3742}}, {{item:3143}}, {{item:3110}} etc. I don't think armor itemisation is really that bad, it's more just an issue of AD itemisation being too strong. In particular, {{item:3142}} and {{item:3147}} need nerfs, but a nerf to anything with Zeal in it probably wouldn't go astray either.

Also,

>It feels like individual classes reach their mid/late game status sooner than others.

This is a normal part of the game, I don't get why you'd complain about this. It's just part of balancing that some champions will tend to accelerate at different rates. It's OK to reach late game status fast if it's difficult to get through the early game, for example. Not saying this is the case currently, but I think it'd better to complain about the lack of conceivable weaknesses for some champions (e.g. Corki) rather than the rate at which they reach a certain power spike.

Finally, just a small personal suggestion if Rito ever reads this thread:

{{champion:238}} can easily be fixed by reducing the range on his ult's RETURN (when he uses it to escape after comboing). Currently his R has extremely large range - if you somehow walk like halfway across the map you can still basically return to his shadow. If there were more risk associated with flashing/W dashing after a fleeing enemy, it'd make Zed require more skill without making him strictly weaker. Give his ult return the range of, say, a Lux Q.

I agree on the zed ult change. The armor items you pointed out are kind of niche. DMP is great in basically every situation, but FH's mana means you won't always be able to get maximum efficiency when buying it. Not saying it's a bad armor item, but it's kind of situational. Randuins is alright, but if the enemy team doesn't really have much crits it's not as potent (granted, 10% reduction isn't too big of a deal). It seems like there's a lot of strong mr options like {{item:3065}} {{item:3190}} and {{item:3102}}, and there are more items that are more bruiser/adc options for more survivability {{item:3139}}  {{item:3156}}. 

I suppose the problem isn't necessarily not enough armor on items but not enough items with armor. Most are situational and it's difficult to itemize with it unless you're a tank or a bruiser who has gotten his first item already.
